title: Hiring Bar Inflation
context: Companies adopt the mantra 'only hire the best' and raise the hiring bar continuously. Each new hire must be better than the average of the existing team. Interview processes expand to 5-8 rounds. Take-home projects consume 10-20 hours. The bar rises until it filters out qualified candidates who could do the job well but don't perform optimally in artificial interview conditions. The process selects for interview skills, not job skills. Meanwhile, positions stay open for months, existing team members burn out covering the gap, and the company loses candidates to competitors with faster processes. The irony: the 'best' candidates — those with multiple offers — are the ones most likely to drop out of a lengthy process. The hiring bar that was supposed to ensure quality actually selects for candidates who have the luxury of time and the specific skill of interviewing well.
hypothesis: Only hiring the best ensures a high-performing team.

children.label: Best candidates with multiple offers drop out first
Take-home projects filter for free time, not ability
Process selects for interview skills, not job skills
Existing team burns out covering the gap
Cost of vacancy exceeds cost of a 'good enough' hire
Interviewers hire people who remind them of themselves

dontIf: Your interview process takes more than 2 weeks end-to-end
You can't demonstrate that your hiring bar correlates with actual job performance
ifYouMust: Measure correlation between interview performance and actual job performance
Cap interview rounds at 4 and total candidate time at 5 hours
Track cost of vacancy alongside cost of a 'wrong' hire
Use structured interviews with rubrics to reduce bias and increase signal

alternatives.name: Trial periods
alternatives.note: Hire faster with a 90-day evaluation period — real work beats interviews

alternatives.name: Structured interviews only
alternatives.note: 4 rounds max with standardized questions and rubrics

alternatives.name: Hire for potential
alternatives.note: Hire people who can grow into the role, not just those who already fit perfectly

sources.title: Google: Rethinking the Hiring Process
sources.note: Google found that interview scores beyond 4 rounds added no predictive value for job performance

sources.title: Harvard Business Review: The Cost of a Bad Hire vs Empty Seat
sources.note: Research showing the cost of an unfilled position often exceeds the cost of a mediocre hire

sources.title: Greenhouse: Hiring Process Length and Candidate Experience
sources.note: Data showing candidate drop-off increases 10% for each additional interview round

sources.title: Frank Schmidt: Validity of Selection Methods
sources.note: Meta-analysis showing structured interviews predict job performance better than unstructured multi-round processes

falsifiability: Companies with 6+ interview rounds hire measurably better performers than those with 3-4 rounds
Raising the hiring bar reduces time-to-fill rather than increasing it
Interview performance strongly predicts actual job performance (r > 0.5)

seo.description: Hiring bar inflation extends time-to-fill 300% while candidate drop-off hits 60%. The process selects for interview skills, not job skills — and the best candidates leave first.
